Project Description  To help achieve health-related MDGs of the Philippines, the Project 
will address low and inefficient public expenditures in health care by 
mobilizing additional off-budget credit for pro-poor investment through 
a government financial intermediary, leveraging private participation, 
and improving allocation toward investment priorities. These priorities 
include  (i)  maternal  and  child  health  services,  (ii)  control  of 
communicable  diseases,  (iii) services  to  improve  access  to  basic 
health care, and (iv) referral services including laboratory and other 
diagnostic services.   
 
The Project will support DBP’s Sustainable Health Care Investment 
Program, a credit facility established in 2007 to support the health 
sector  reform  agenda  and  implementation  framework—Fourmula 
One for Health (F1)—of the Department of Health (DOH). The credit 
facility is available to local government units (LGUs), and the private 
sector through two windows (i) direct retail lending for LGUs and 
larger  private  sector  subborrowers,  and  (ii)  wholesale  lending  to 
accredited financial intermediaries (microfinance intermediaries, rural 
and  thrift  banks)  for  small  private  subborrowers.  The  Investment 
Program is financed from DBP’s own resources and supplementary 
funds  of  development  partners,  and  supports  both  capital 
investments and working capital. 
 
The Project’s outputs are (i) upgraded LGU health services, (ii) more 
efficient  health  delivery  systems  through  public–private  partnership 
(PPP) and innovative strategies, (iii) improved access to small-scale 
private providers, and (iv) enhanced institutional capacity for health 
sector lending. 
   
Rationale  The Government of the Philippines (the Government) is committed to 
meeting the country's MDGs. The Philippines MDG Report for 2007 
highlights the mixed achievements, and especially the slow progress 
in  reducing  maternal  mortality,  and  the  need  for  better  health 
services.

ii   
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  supports  the  Government’s 
plans  for  mobilizing  off-budget  resources  through  government 
financial institutions, the private sector, nongovernment organizations 
(NGOs), and civil society.  
 
ADB’s Health Sector Development Program (2004–2010) supported 
key policy reforms and implementation of DOH’s F1 for health. The 
Project is in line with ADB’s Strategy 2020 (involving MDGs, PPP, 
public expenditure management) and will enable ADB to continue 
policy dialogue on health sector development. 
 
The Project will address a key bottleneck in the implementation of 
DOH’s F1 by providing credit to upgrade health facilities. This will not 
only improve health services, but will trigger higher reimbursement of 
the  Philippine  Health  Insurance  Corporation  (PHIC)  and  thereby 
reduce  the  cost  of  health  care  for  the  poor,  which  in  turn  will 
contribute to achieving MDGs.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The impact of the Project is improved overall health status, especially 
in relation to MDGs by (i) reduced under-five child mortality rate and 
reduced  infant  mortality  rate  (MDG  4),  and  (ii) reduced  maternal 
mortality ratio (MDG 5). The Project’s outcome is increased use of 
basic health care and referral services by the poor in general, and by 
women and children in particular, in the subproject sites. The Project 
will be nationwide, with the exception of the National Capital Region.

Project Benefits and  Health  Benefits.  The  Project  is  designed  to  address  MDGs  by 
Beneficiaries  targeting the poor, in particular women and children with poor health 
indicators.  It  specifically  addresses  gaps  in  basic  health  care, 
including  maternal  and  child  health  care,  communicable  disease 
control,  diagnostic  services,  and  referral  services.  The  Project 
promotes  the  use  of  PHIC-accredited  health  facilities,  thereby

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed loan; 
and (ii) a proposed administration of a grant to be provided by the Gender and Development 
Cooperation Fund,1 both to the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP) for the Credit for Better 
Health Care Project. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Public–
Private Partnership in Health, and if the Board approves the loan and the grant, I, acting under the 
authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1.   
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  The Government of the Philippines, with its partners, wants to improve health care for its 
population of about 90 million to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and ensure 
timely and adequate response to the changing morbidity patterns in the Philippines. The country’s 
MDG performance is mixed: the infant mortality rate was reportedly reduced to 24 deaths per 1,000 
live births in 2006 and is on track. The malnutrition rate (weight by age) shows little improvement at 
26% but is above the regional average. The maternal mortality ratio has declined to 162 deaths per 
100,000 live births in 2006, and it may not reach MDG targets. Tuberculosis and other communicable 
diseases remain common, and HIV/AIDS is emerging.2 Health indicators in the Eastern Visayas, 
Bicol, and most of Mindanao are particularly lagging. The country’s relatively slow progress in 
health is linked to poverty, rapid population growth, and low investment in health. Health services 
fall short in terms of access and affordability for the poor, quality and efficiency of service delivery, 
and financing of services and investment.  
 
3.  The Philippines has an average per capita income of $1,351, albeit with considerable 
inequity. Economic growth was 7% in 2007 but slowed to 4.6% annually in the first half of 2008. It 
is predicted to slow further to 3%–4% in 2009. Reflecting the global slowdown, exports have fallen 
and so has foreign direct investment. Public sector consumption and investment spending have 
contracted in real terms, and private sector consumption growth is at its lowest since 2001. 
Inflation was a high 7% in 2008 and is rising. It particularly affects the poor, given the high food 
price inflation. The Government has responded by postponing its goal of a balanced budget to 
allow for increased spending in 2008 in infrastructure, social protection, and subsidies.  
 
4.  The robust economic growth in recent years has apparently had little impact on poverty. 
The 2006 poverty level of 33%, or 27.6 million, is similar to the 2000 level. Income inflation is not 
keeping pace with price inflation, especially in recent times. Social safety net programs are limited, 
giving the poor and near poor little protection. Catastrophic events such as the loss of a job or 
hospitalization result in food shortages among the poor, and cause the near poor to slip into 
poverty. In 1997, a sponsored program for the poor was introduced under the Philippine Health 
Insurance Corporation (PHIC) to offset some health care costs, and in 2007, the Ahon Pamilyang 
Pilipino (conditional cash transfer program) was piloted. To improve social protection, the PHIC 
aims to achieve universal enrollment of the poor, with budgetary support from central and local 
governments, and to provide a comprehensive benefits package for the poor.  
 
5.  Health sector spending remains low. In 2005, it was 3.3% of gross domestic product or $40 
per capita. While public expenditures for health have grown in absolute terms, they have not kept 
pace with population and inflationary pressures. Health care is financed from multiple sources,

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
  1.  Philippine Health System and Strategy 
 
8.  The Philippines has a dual health care system of largely tax-financed public health services 
at national and local levels plus an extensive for-profit and nonprofit private sector that is largely 
financed from user fees. Public health services in the Philippines are provided by the Department 
of Health (DOH), LGUs, and other agencies. LGUs finance and operate provincial and district 
hospitals, and municipal governments run rural health units and barangay health stations.5 The 
private health sector includes clinics, hospitals, insurance companies, manufacturers of drugs and 
equipment,  and  training  institutes.6 PHIC  is  a  government-owned  and  controlled  corporation 
attached to DOH, mandated to administer the PHIC program and ensure that Filipinos have 
financial access to health services. 
 
9.  The Philippines health system has gone through several reforms, including devolution of 
health services to local government units in 1991 and the national health insurance act in 1995 that 
included the nonformal sector. In 1999, DOH launched the health sector reform agenda to improve 
the sector’s delivery, regulation, and financing. In 2005, DOH launched Fourmula One for Health 
(F1)—the reform’s implementation framework for 2005–2010. F1 is directed toward achieving 
better  health  outcomes,  a  more  responsive  health  system,  and  more  equitable  health  care 
financing (especially for the poor). Its four objectives are to (i) secure more, better, and sustained 
financing for health care; (ii) assure the quality and affordability of health goods and services; (iii) 
ensure access to and availability of essential and basic health care packages; and (iv) improve 
performance of the health system. F1 is designed to implement critical health interventions as a 
single package, backed by effective management infrastructure and financing arrangements. It 
engages the entire health sector, including public and private services, development partners, and 
civil society, and it is the basis for DOH’s medium-term expenditure framework (2007–2010). It

10.  A key feature of F1 is to engage PHIC as the main lever to effect each of the four reform 
areas under a single national implementation plan and under single local health investment plans 
in the first batch of 16 provinces. DOH wants to scale up the reforms and build ownership in all 
provinces by 2010. The sector needs, however, to address multiple challenges, including (i) limited 
access to and affordability of health care for the poor, (ii) inadequate quality and inefficiency of service 
delivery, (iii) lack of delivery standards and accountability mechanisms, and (iv) limited financing and 
access to credit for operating services properly and investing in buildings and equipment. All of these 
need to be addressed under F1 to achieve the MDGs and adjust to the changing demographic and 
epidemiological situation.  
 
11.  The Project will help address these challenges in implementing F1 and SDAH by providing 
credit  to  both  LGUs  and  private  providers  to  upgrade  health  facilities  in  order  to  obtain 
accreditation and provide better health services. In addition to the direct benefits of better services, 
accreditation will trigger PHIC reimbursement. That will reduce the cost of health care for the poor, 
which in turn will contribute to achieving MDGs. Government oversight, provincial plans, eligibility 
criteria for providers and subprojects, marketing, and monitoring will assist in targeting maternal 
and child health and the poor in general. The introduction of new packages for maternal and child 
health and outpatient care currently under preparation by PHIC will further trigger access and 
quality enhancement while increasing affordability. The health sector analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
2.  Access and Affordability  
 
12.  Demand for health services remains low among the poor and vulnerable groups.8 This may be 
due to a variety of reasons, including (i) the relatively high cost of medical care, drugs and transport; 
(ii) social and cultural biases of both patients and providers; (iii) lack of understanding of modern 
medical care; and (iv) limited geographical access to services. Households have limited information on 
health benefits and costs, and they may be reluctant to use services due to the perceived poor quality 
or high cost of care. Only 37% of users of public hospitals were satisfied with public health services 
(footnote 8). Facility-based childbirth remains low among the poor (11% among the poor, versus 38% 
overall in 2003). Child immunization coverage is also lower (55% among the poor, versus 70% overall 
in 2003). The poor primarily use the barangay health stations or rural health units for health care 
because of access and affordability considerations (79%). When possible, however, lower level care 
is bypassed for higher-level care even when not needed, contributing to low occupancy rates (20%–
40%) in district hospitals and overuse of provincial hospitals. System reforms and investments for 
upgrading are required that will redistribute demand by appropriate levels of care.  
 
13.  The cost of health care, including for drugs, is a key reason for the low utilization by the poor.

5.  Financing and Access to Credit 
 
24.  Under the Local Government Code (LGC) of 1991, health service delivery was devolved to 
LGUs, and provinces and municipalities are required to cover capital and recurrent expenditures 
for services under their responsibility, including those for health care. An LGU’s budget is sourced 
through (i) national government internal revenue allotment (IRA),19 and (ii) local government tax-
based revenues and income-generation programs. Revenues of provinces and municipalities vary 
widely, however, and several LGUs greatly depend on national government financial support.

mandated in the LGC and no formula is used for its allocation. LGUs have often not kept to LGC 
recommendations. For example, personnel expenses have increased significantly (to represent on 
average 69% of the LGU budget), thereby reducing operating expenses to almost half (averaging 
30% of the LGU budget). LGU recurrent spending on health care is insufficient for drugs and 
supplies and for communicable disease control programs. Capital outlays for health care have 
been  very  low  (on  average  at  2%  of  LGU  health  spending).  Bottlenecks  that  constrain

infrastructure development, capital investment, and, in some cases, operating expenses, but they

graduating LGUs to creditworthy status in order to access private sources of capital. LGUs are 
constrained in borrowing from the private capital markets, however, due to (i) a limited number of

collateral, thus preventing normal creditor-borrower relationships from being established; and (iii)

longer term for reasons of financial sustainability while private markets lend for shorter terms.

in the health sector.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
42.  The impact of the Project is improved overall health status, especially in relation to MDG 4 
(reduce child mortality), and MDG 5 (improve maternal health) by 2015. The Project’s outcome is 
increased use of basic health care and referral services by the poor in general, and by women and 
children in particular, in the subproject sites. The Project will be nationwide,29 with the exception of 
the National Capital Region.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
43.  The project outputs are (i) upgraded LGU health services, (ii) more efficient health care 
delivery systems through PPP and innovative strategies, (iii) improved access to small-scale private 
providers, and (iv) enhanced institutional capacity for health sector lending. 
 
44.  The  Project  supports  DBP’s  recently  established  credit  program  for  the  health  sector.

public and private sectors, and (ii) wholesale relending through accredited financial intermediaries

intermediary lending modality.

2.  More  Efficient  Health  Care  Delivery  Systems  through  Public–Private 
Partnership and Innovative Strategies 
 
51.  This output will support PPP and innovative strategies that aim to build an integrated health 
care delivery system, as well as to improve efficiency, quality, and cost-risk sharing. Both public 
and private providers will be given access to credit for capital investment and/or working capital. 
PPP options may include health care facility construction, financing, management, and services 
delivery. Types of eligible subprojects are (i) outsourcing technical, medical (e.g., to cooperatives), 
and ancillary services; (ii) outsourcing support services such as security, housekeeping, food 
services, and laundry; (iii) contracting in the management of a public facility; (iv) contracting private 
providers to deliver health services; and (v) contracting private insurance schemes for specific 
populations. Innovative strategies could include generic drug bulk procurement or consignment, 
establishment of telemedicine, and strengthening management systems. The Project will help 
LGUs conduct feasibility studies to examine potentially cost-effective options for consideration by 
the Health Sector Investment Advisory Committee (see para. 68). The Project will lend to about 
three to four PPP subprojects.

access to quality maternal and child health services, as well as to complement the public system 
where such shortages exist as for medical personnel in some rural areas. DBP’s accredited 
financial intermediaries (MFIs, cooperatives, and rural and thrift banks) will access credit from 
DBP’s program for onlending to locations underperforming in public health priorities. DBP will be 
relending project funds to about 20 of DBP’s accredited financial intermediaries, which in turn will 
onlend to about 2,100 end subprojects. The potential subborrowers are about 1,800 midwifery 
clinics, 200 clinical and diagnostic facilities, 100 community drug stores (botika ng bayan), and 10 
drug distribution companies catering to rural municipalities. 
 
53.  Upgrading Private Services. Financial intermediaries will access credit for onlending to 
private, small-scale health services providers for civil works to meet or improve PHIC accreditation 
standards. Eligible investments will include civil works (construction and rehabilitation) for clinics, 
drug stores, and diagnostic centers. Drug distribution companies catering to rural municipalities will 
be eligible for investment in drug warehouses. Private sector, small-scale health services providers

literacy, sustainable health care enterprise development (particularly in making their services more 
accessible and affordable to these potential end-borrowers), and compliance with environmental 
risk mitigation (standards set and recommended by DOH). The training program is expected to

development, program evaluation, and marketing group to manage and monitor health sector 
projects, including to form close collaboration with PHIC for setting up contracts with subborrowers.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.   Expected Benefits and Impacts 
 
92.  Health  Benefits.  The Project is designed to address MDGs by targeting the poor, in 
particular women and children with poor health indicators. It specifically addresses gaps in basic 
health care, including maternal and child health care, communicable disease control, diagnostic 
services, and referral services. The Project promotes the use of PHIC-accredited health facilities, 
thereby promoting quality standards of services, and it supports partnership between the public 
and private sectors to address gaps in health care, such as staff shortages for maternal care.  
 
93.  Social, Gender, and Poverty Benefits. The Project is designed to result in major social, 
gender, and poverty benefits with multiple impacts. A larger proportion of the beneficiaries will be 
the poor, women, and children. They will benefit from upgrading LGU health facilities and also from 
filling gaps in service delivery through PPP and support for small providers close to communities. 
Oversight arrangements, capacity development, provincial plans, eligibility criteria, and targeted 
funding for assisting small providers will help to ensure that suitable subprojects are selected that 
yield maximum benefit for these vulnerable groups. The Project also supports PHIC accreditation 
of health providers close to the underserved population. Finally, the Project provides improved 
access to credit and opportunities for improved earnings for small-scale health providers, who are 
often female (midwives, drug store owners). The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is 
in Appendix 13, and the gender and development action plan is in Appendix 14. 
 
94.  Financial Protection of the Poor. The poor will benefit (i) through reduced costs for care 
and transport, plus greater opportunity to receive care, as facilities become more accessible; (ii) 
from increased subsidy from PHIC-accredited health facilities, including generic drug outlets, and 
(iii) indirectly, through better health resulting in less income erosion and increased productivity. 
 
95.  Economic Benefits. The subprojects will address (i) externalities, such as through primary 
health care; (ii) merit goods, such as through direct impact on woman and child health, reduction in 
unnecessary use of hospitals, and better information to consumers; (iii) uncertainty, such as due to 
complications during childbirth; and (iv) inequity in access. The Project will promote both technical 
(e.g.,  access  to  affordable  generic  drugs)  and  allocative  (e.g.,  access  to  cost-effective 
interventions) efficiencies. It is expected to have a significant impact on the poor, particularly women 
and  children.  A  cost-effectiveness  analysis  was  undertaken  on  two  subgroups  (i)  infants  and 
particularly neonates; and (ii) women of childbearing age, particularly those who are pregnant. The 
assumption is that as access to credit increases, and health care providers are accredited, more 
women will deliver under health care providers. This will result in healthier women and newborns. 
The Project could therefore essentially bring down maternal and neonatal deaths in the subproject 
sites. While the analysis focuses on infant and maternal deaths, many of these interventions should 
also reduce infant and maternal distress and morbidity. Consequently, total health benefits, as 
measured by a composite measure such as disability-adjusted life years, would be significantly 
greater. In the 15th year from the start of the investment, the Project will maximize net benefits 
accruing to the country (positive net present value) and the internal rate of return will surpass the 
discount rate. An economic and financial sustainability analysis is in Supplementary Appendix G.

23 
96.  Financial Sustainability. Analyses were undertaken to assess the financial sustainability of 
subprojects, and these were broken down to (i) retail lending subprojects, and (ii) wholesale lending 
subprojects. An actual case of a LGU provincial hospital expansion was taken from one province. 
Additionally, for wholesale lending, actual costs and estimated incomes were considered for small-
scale health providers, such as midwives, obstetricians, and drug stores. The financial sustainability 
analysis was determined by using weighted average cost of capital and financial internal rate of return 
estimates for each subproject, and composite financial internal rate of return for the Project. The 
analysis suggests that the Project is generally financially sustainable. However, LGU hospitals, which 
are not income-generating entities and generally rely on LGUs cross-subsidization, under the current 
budget scenario are dependent on PHIC reimbursements for sustained operation expenditures. There 
is risk of increase in balance billing, as hospitals may try to increase user fees (charged to patients) in 
response to their increased capital investment. The subprojects will mitigate this risk by contracting 
with PHIC, which stipulates hospital charges for its beneficiaries. Most small-scale subprojects were 
financially sustainable, although the sensitivity analysis suggests that they could be vulnerable if 
revenue generation is delayed.  
 
B.   Assumptions, Risks, and Mitigating Measures 
 
97.  Key  assumptions  for  successful  implementation  are  (i)  adequate  recurrent  and  capital 
budgets by Government and LGUs for health-related programs, (ii) enrollment of indigents and the 
poor  into  PHIC,  (iii)  provider  access  to  a  comprehensive  PHIC  benefits  and  reimbursements 
package, and (iv) LGUs and private health entrepreneurs are willing and able to borrow at DBP’s 
(or financial intermediaries’) terms. Some risks and mitigating measures are given below. 
 
98.  Delayed Implementation of F1. To date, DOH has mobilized 37 out of the 78 provinces to 
achieve F1 and it plans to cover all by 2010. If the mobilization of LGUs or the preparation of LGU 
investments  is  delayed,  project  disbursement  will  be  delayed.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  DBP,  in 
partnership  with  DOH  and  DILG,  will  need  to  ensure  the  timely  mobilization  of  LGUs  and 
preparation of the subproject feasibility studies.   
 
99.  Limited Experience in the Health Sector. While DBP has established a new credit facility 
for health development projects, it has limited experience in the health sector. Its experience has 
primarily been in large-scale private projects, where it was not necessary to provide TA or whose 
performance  could  easily  be  monitored.  DBP  is  well-versed  with  financial  management  and 
assessing creditworthiness. DBP will also need to market its new lending product to generate 
demand among LGU and small-scale subborrowers. DBP will obtain expertise in the health sector 
and form partnerships with other key agencies—DOH and MDFO in particular. Under the LGU 
credit policy framework, DBP and MDFO form an alliance in lending to LGUs.

HEALTH SECTOR ANALYSIS   
 
A.  The Sector 
 
1.  The Government of the Philippines and its partners need to close the gap in access to 
health care, especially for the poor and for those in the rural areas, in order to achieve the 
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and ensure timely and adequate response to changing 
morbidity patterns in the country. This appendix summarizes the sector, what can be done to 
close the gap, and the role of the Development Bank of the Philippines (DBP).  
 
2.  Filipinos’ life expectancy at birth is 71 years (2005) on average, but remote provinces 
have much lower life expectancies.1 The country has a mixed status on the health-related 
MDGs. The Philippines National Statistics Office reports that the infant mortality rate (IMR) had 
steadily declined to 31 infant deaths per 1,000 live births by 2004, and the maternal mortality 
ratio (MMR) was at 200 per 100,000 live births in 2000 and 108 in 2003. Both IMR and MMR 
are higher in the Visayas and Mindanao compared to Luzon. The MMR is much higher in Bicol, 
Leyte, and Samar. Maternal and child deaths in remote areas are likely to be underreported. 
The IMR for children whose mothers have no education is 65 deaths per 1,000 live births 
compared with 15 deaths per 1,000 live births for children whose mothers have college or 
higher education. Although the MMR also shows major disparities by income status, it remains 
relatively high, too, among the more affluent, thus demonstrating that this is not just a matter of 
access and affordability but also one of quality of care.   
 
3.  Noncommunicable diseases (like asthma, heart diseases, hypertension, and cancers) 
have been increasing, causing early morbidity, disability, and mortality as well as a drain on 
health care resources. Long existent and treatable infectious diseases are reemerging and 
becoming more difficult to treat because of increased vulnerability and drug resistance. New 
infectious  diseases  are  emerging  (human  immunodeficiency  virus  [HIV],  severe  acute 
respiratory  syndrome,  avian  influenza).  HIV  prevalence  has  increased  slowly,  although  it 
remains concentrated in high risk groups. 
 
4.  Immediate attention is required to the slow progress in attaining the health-related MDGs 
and  to improve  prevention  and early  curing  of incapacitating  diseases.  The  large  regional 
disparities point to the need for giving specific attention to deprived regions and to the deprived 
and vulnerable categories of the population (in rural areas and urban slums).  
 
5.  The Philippines has a dual health system of largely tax-financed public health services at 
national and local levels plus an extensive for-profit and nonprofit private sector that is largely 
financed from user fees. Social health insurance has been introduced and is being expanded 
gradually as a way of pooling risk, establishing accreditation, and contracting services. This is 
expected to improve access for the poor and vulnerable, although the range of reimbursable 
services and access to quality services remain limited.       
 
6.  Public  health  services  are  provided  by  the  Department  of  Health  (DOH),  local 
government units (LGUs), and other agencies (e.g., the military). DOH provides national health 
policies, plans, standards, and guidelines. DOH at central level comprises the Secretary’s office 
and five clusters for sector management, internal management, regulation, external affairs, and 
local health programs. DOH has three zonal health offices headed by undersecretaries and 
mandated to implement the national health objectives, the Local Government Code, and the 
health sector reform agenda. It operates 16 centers for health development—one in each

operates about 70 national, regional, and specialty hospitals.  
 
7.  The  Philippines  Health  Insurance  Corporation  (PHIC)  is  a  government-owned  and 
controlled  corporation  attached  to  DOH.  It  is  mandated  to  administer  the  national  health 
insurance program and ensure that Filipinos have affordable access to health services. The 
private health sector includes clinics, hospitals, insurance companies, manufacturers of drugs 
and equipment, training institutes, and other entities.  
 
8.  LGUs finance and operate provincial and district hospitals, while municipal governments 
run rural health units (RHUs) and barangay health stations (BHSs). Every LGU has a health 
board to advise the executive on health care system development. In 2002, there were about 
661 government hospitals (up from 413 in 1980) and 1,077 private hospitals (down from 1,194 
in 1980). The bed capacity declined in this period from 18.2 to 10.7 beds per 10,000 people. As 
would be expected, most hospital beds are in the National Capital Region and the least in the 
Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao. An RHU serves about 40,000 people and a BHS 
about 5,000. The number of RHUs declined from 1,962 in 1986 to 1,879 in 2001, and the 
number of BHSs increased from 9,184 in 1988 to 15,343 in 2002.                   
 
9.  In 2002, LGUs employed 3,021 doctors, 1,871 dentists, 4,720 nurses, 16,534 midwives, 
3,271  engineers,  1,505  medical  technologists,  and  other  staff.  There  were  also  195,928 
barangay health volunteers and 54,557 birth attendants (footnote 1). The Philippines is among 
the biggest exporters of nurses and doctors, leading to staff shortages and quality constraints. 
Filipinos have high per capita spending on medicines, totaling about half of total spending on 
health care. The market is dominated by expensive branded medicines.  
 
10.  While  the  Philippines  health  care  system  is  generally  extensive,  access  to  health 
services—particularly by the poor—is hampered by high costs plus physical and sociocultural 
barriers. The health care system has gone through several reforms, including the adoption of 
primary health care approach in 1979, integration of public health and hospital services in 1983, 
devolution of health services to LGUs in 1991, and enactment of the National Health Insurance 
Act in 1995 that included the nonformal sector. In 1999, DOH launched the health sector reform 
agenda to improve the delivery, regulation, and financing of the sector.  
 
11.  Fourmula One for Health (F1) is DOH’s implementation framework for health sector 
reforms for the medium term covering 2005–2010. It is directed to achieving better health 
outcomes, a more responsive health care system, and more equitable health care financing in a 
manner that is felt and appreciated by Filipinos, especially the poor. This is consistent with the 
health system goals identified by the World Health Organization (WHO), the MDGs, and the 
medium-term Philippine development plan. FI has four specific medium-term objectives:  
(i)  secure more, better, and sustained financing for health;  
(ii)  assure the quality and affordability of health goods and services;  
(iii)  ensure access to and availability of essential and basic health packages; and 
(iv)  improve performance of the health system.  
 
12.  F1 is designed to implement critical health interventions as a single package, backed by 
effective management infrastructure and financing arrangements. It engages the entire health 
sector,  including  the  public  and  private  sectors,  national  agencies  and  LGUs,  external 
development agencies, and civil society to get involved in the implementation of health reforms.

B.  Main Issues 
 
13.  The current system is fragmented in its organization and management, in its services, 
and in financing. In effect, a two-tier system exists: the private sector for the rich (mainly located 
in the cities) and the public system for the poor. Health system funding shows a problematic mix 
that is part national health system, part social health insurance system, and combined with a 
halfway devolved system providing mandates for regulating and financing the sector to DOH, 
LGUs, and PHIC (all of which deal with the same health service providers, both publicly and 
privately owned). The public system lacks funding, instruments for stewardship and regulatory 
capacity, enforcement and effective use of existing regulation, and incentives for health care 
providers.  There  are  major  challenges—but  also  opportunities—in  improving  access, 
affordability, quality, management, and financing of health services.  
 
1.  Access  
14.  A 2003 survey identified problems of financial, geographic, and cultural access to health 
care.2 Better health services were characterized as follows (i) health professional are reliable, 
(ii) drugs and diagnostic equipment are available, and (iii) the building is clean and people are 
treated with dignity. People equate good staff attitude and cleanliness with quality care, which is 
often seen as lacking in public health services. Availability of free or inexpensive (generic) drugs 
is appreciated but patients have more confidence in branded drugs. Demand for preventive 
health care is low. Use of traditional healers is still widely practiced before and after visiting a 
modern clinic.  
 
15.  According to the same survey (footnote 2), facility-based deliveries increased from 34% 
in the 5 years preceding 1998 to 38% in the 5 years preceding the 2003 survey. Sixty percent of 
births in the 5 years before the 2003 survey were assisted by health professionals (34% by a 
doctor and 26% by a midwife or a nurse) compared with 56% in the 5 years preceding the 1998 
survey (footnote 2). WHO recommends that every delivery should take place in a well-equipped 
health facility, and be led by a health professional. Regional variation ranges from fewer than 
40% of births assisted by health professionals in Bicol, Caraga, and Autonomous Region in 
Muslim Mindanao to over 80% in Central Luzon and the National Capital Region. Importantly, in 
38% of cases of maternal death there was no medical attendance.  
 
16.  The use of services is slightly higher for public health services and quite evenly spread 
across the country, although slightly higher in urban areas. A major problem is the bypassing of 
public facilities or going straight to tertiary care facilities when primary or secondary care would 
have been sufficient. This is due to the perceived low quality of care and unavailability of 
medicines. Many government hospitals have inadequate budgetary support and managerial 
autonomy after devolution. Private services are perceived to offer better quality care, to be 
similar in terms of access, but to be more costly. Public health services are more often used by 
the poor who cannot afford private services. 
 
17.  District hospitals, although classified as secondary hospitals, are often structured as 
primary care hospitals (under 50 beds), and they offer limited specialist and diagnostic services. 
Provincial hospitals are structured as secondary care hospitals, have specialist and diagnostic 
services  with  limited  capacity,  but  are  located  in  larger  towns  and  cities.  Nongovernment 
secondary care hospitals are mostly located in urban areas. Most hospital beds are in urban 
tertiary hospitals. The current PHIC-operated accreditation system creates an incentive for

status as “tertiary,” because they are then automatically accredited (while other hospital levels

This cannot happen, however, without upgrading lower level health services providers, like

2.  Affordability 
18.  Some 33% of Filipinos are classified as poor, while 20% of the urban population and 47% 
of the rural people are poor. Almost half of health care costs are paid out-of-pocket, while PHIC 
contributes only 10% of these costs.3 Fees for services may deter the poor from seeking health 
services at all or may cause greater poverty, indebtedness, and loss of land. The poor will often 
not be able to afford basic health care (and therefore often delay care until it is too late, which 
particularly affects children). Also, the nonpoor may find it difficult to pay for catastrophic and 
chronic care. If not deferring treatment, families use other strategies to meet their health care 
needs,  including  self-medication,  sharing  medicine,  and  going  into  debt  for  severe  illnesses 
(including for terminal illnesses of the elderly). Given high levels of unemployment and prevailing 
social structures, income generators may also end up in poverty while caring for dependents.  
 
19.  Drugs constitute half of health expenditures. Except for the indigent, PHIC does not yet 
offer reimbursement for outpatient drugs. The absence of such reimbursement may be cause 
for unnecessary hospital admission, not only because of forgone prevention opportunities but 
also simply to obtain medicines inside a hospital that are unaffordable to patients in outpatient 
care. DOH is addressing this issue by gradually expanding access to simple drugstores via its 
system of botika ng barangay (community-managed drug outlets), which offer a limited variety 
of essential drugs at low prices procured via international competitive bidding by Philippine 
International Trading Corporation.  
 
3.  Quality of Care 
20.  There  is  no  accountability  for  quality  of  services  provided  at  health  facilities.  The 
Philippines  has  licensing  (through  DOH)  and  an  accreditation  program  (through  PHIC)  for 
hospitals and other health care facilities, and the PHIC reports that about 90% of all hospitals 
and 40% of all rural health clinics are accredited. However, the PHIC accreditation program 
currently does not meet international standards. PHIC accreditation standards are more or less 
like the licensing program of DOH—aiming for the facility to have the minimum inputs needed to 
function (human resources and equipment) but not looking at hospitals  more comprehensively 
(in terms of organization and systems). Further, many hospitals that should qualify for a higher 
level of care are unable to meet the standards and are therefore accredited for a lower level of 
care  (e.g.,  secondary  rather  than  tertiary).  This  is  due  to  requirements  for  infrastructure, 
equipment, or human resource not being met. 
 
21.  Accreditation standards complying with international requirements will be introduced in

22.  The Philippines has to face a national shortage of physicians and nurses, as many leave 
the country to work elsewhere. There is an apparent lack of coordinated incentives to keep 
essential health staff in the country, and especially in rural areas. The DOH-supported “Doctors 
to the Barrios” program is a good initiative. Medical students have their studies subsidized by 
DOH on condition that they work for 2 years in the barrios. It is a successful program, but it is

23.  Doctors  and  pharmacists  seem  to  have  an  interest  in  prescribing  and  dispensing 
branded drugs instead of generics. PHIC has no instruments—such as contracting—to exercise 
control over prescribing and dispensing drugs. While markets are not working and third party 
health care payers are not effective, a more active market regulatory policy by the Government 
could bring more balance to the market while stimulating real competition on price and quality.  
 
24.  Pharmacies are regulated to assure the delivery of safe drugs to the patient, but the 
distribution  of  pharmacies  across  the  country  is  not  regulated.  This  may  cause  access 
problems. In addition, antitrust regulation is absent or insufficiently used, leaving the drugs 
distribution to a few wholesalers and with consequences for the distribution of low-cost drugs. 
DOH  is  trying  to  solve  this  problem  by  stimulating  the  establishment  of  20,000  botika  ng 
barangay by 2015 that would offer generic essential drugs.  
 
4.  Management 
25.  On the national and LGU levels, the country lacks adequate instruments for stewardship 
and insufficient regulatory and enforcement capacity for planning and distribution of health care 
resources, for provider performance review, and for quality assurance. As a consequence, 
many small (less than 50 beds) hospitals (most of these doctor- or family-owned) have difficulty 
coping with requirements for quality and continuity of care. While some hospitals have high 
occupancy rates, are overcrowded, and need to place beds in corridors, others have very low 
occupancy rates and very short length of stay. This points to an ill-conceived and ill-planned 
system. DOH is working in its health reform program, together with selected provinces, to 
develop provincial investment plans for health. These plans (for which financing is essential) 
should facilitate targeted investments and better access to upgraded health care facilities.  
 
26.  Public and private hospitals and clinics often lack managerial capacity, primarily because 
the facilities are run not by trained management specialists but by clinical staff. In addition, 
appropriate hardware  and software are not installed for information management, financial 
management, claims processing, patient management, and patient record keeping. That means 
financial and quality auditing are more difficult and costly. The lack of inventory systems also 
results in poor drug management and dangerous stock-outs. The system inefficiencies have 
been costly. Alternative options need to be explored, including to strengthen in-house capacity 
for management or outsourcing to third parties. A DOH initiative to train health managers 
contributes to solving the problems, but it is on a too-small scale.

27.  Some  nongovernment  hospitals  are  outsourcing  medical  waste  management, 
housekeeping,  security,  payment  claims  processing,  and  medical  and  office  equipment 
maintenance. The company Philam, for example, provides claims processing services to health 
maintenance organizations. The Philippine training institutions produce adequate skills in the 
areas of management, information technology, and accounting, but such skills have not been 
sufficiently  tapped  for  outsourcing  public  sector  institutional  or  health  facility  management. 
Benefits from economies of scale may be realized by outsourcing support and ancillary services 
from government and nongovernment health facilities.  
 
28.  Although the devolution of power and stewardship functions in the health sector to the 
LGUs has its good aspects (such as better involvement and catering to local health needs), 
devolution has made it difficult to implement national policies and health objectives. DOH has 
only advisory power vis-à-vis the LGUs on some of the issues critical for the proposed DBP 
health care investment program. The LGUs have limited capacity and means for adequately 
directing the health sector in their areas and for managing the health care facilities under their 
responsibility. Implementing rationalization of health services in the provinces has proven to be 
difficult, despite the support of DOH. LGUs do not always take into account the capacity of the 
private sector and sometimes do not have data on its distribution, function, and capacity. 
Exclusion of the private sector from the planning exercise may, in the absence of planning data 
from the private sector, lead to distorted provincial investment plans for health.  
     
5.  Financing  
29.  About 3.4% of gross domestic product is spent on health (footnote 3). That is low 
compared with the WHO-advised level of 5% for middle-income countries. The larger part of this 
is spent on tertiary hospital services. The public tends to bypass lower facilities and access 
tertiary hospitals even for relatively minor problems. The funding arrangements make it difficult 
to regulate the sector by financial means.  
 
30.  The country has not made a clear choice for either a budget-funded system, eventually 
to be combined with devolution to LGUs, or an insurance-funded system. Mandated pooling of 
funding and, subsequently, a single-payer system do not exist. This leads to fragmentation of 
both funding and of care, with subsequent administrative and health care inefficiencies. In such 
a fragmented system, none of the government bodies has sufficient regulatory enforcement or 
financial clout to effectively and efficiently govern the system of public and private providers.  
 
31.  Health care is financed by multiple payers and from at least four different main sources: 
the national budget (16.7%), the LGU budget (17.5%), PHIC (9.5%), private insurers, and 
private out-of-pocket spending at the point of service (48%).  
 
32.  PHIC funding is also out of balance. While the national health insurance system is 
compulsory, it effectively coverings only 75% of the population. It has difficulty enrolling the rich, 
such as the self-employed like lawyers and doctors. PHIC tries to expand the enrollment of the 
poor via an LGU-sponsored program for the indigent. Formal employers and employees pay 
income-dependent contributions, while the informal sector pays a flat and comparably low 
premium of P1,200 per year to allow the poor to become members of PHIC. Overseas foreign 
workers and their dependents in the Philippines pay an even lower premium of P900 per year. 
 
33.  As there is little or no coordination between these various sources of funding, there 
exists  none  of  the  potential  leverage  that  a  single-payer  system  could  have  vis-à-vis  the 
providers.  Assessing  the  performance  of  health  care  providers  is  difficult—and  scarcely

attempted—as they are paid from many different sources and patients are free to choose 
providers (not being bound to use the nearest providers).  
 
34.  Moreover, current payment systems are not well tuned to act as incentives for providing 
care efficiently and at the right level of care. The current fee-for-service system for specialists 
encourages specialists to eagerly accept and keep patients and then to do as much as possible 
for each. Meanwhile, the existing financing for public primary health care is no incentive for 
doing as much as possible at the primary care level. The absence of a referral system further 
contributes to the inappropriate use of care at an unnecessarily high level. Not all LGUs appear 
to transfer their agreed health budgets in full, or they pass the PHIC-received payments to the 
providers, thus sometimes prompting the staff (like midwives) to leave the public sector and go 
into private practice. PHIC has no insight into the funds flows of LGUs, and there is no external 
audit or accountability of the LGUs (e.g., as regards their fully transferring 70% of the capitation 
for enrolling indigent people in PHIC). 
 
35.  The current reimbursement in PHIC’s fee-for-service system leaves little possibility for 
controlling the volume of services and leads to over-servicing by the health care providers. This 
may eventually be to the detriment of patients’ health, and it will certainly lead to draining away 
scarce resources. Legally and practically, therefore, PHIC has no effective relationship with 
(especially) the private providers other than through the accreditation system to influence the 
quality of care. It is considering, however, to introduce a contracting system together with a 
case-based payment system, but only for inpatient care. If properly monitored and if the case-
based payment system is capped by a maximum budget per hospital, this may alleviate some of 
the counterproductive incentives and supply-induced demand.  
 
36.  While funding constraints result in the health system’s insufficiently responding to the 
population’s preventive and curative health needs, PHIC nevertheless has rather high financial 
reserves that are unnecessary for assuring its solvency and which could be easily and wisely 
spent in the sector.  
 
C.  Conclusions and Recommendations 
 
37.  To close the gap in access to health care, several measures are needed, including the 
following: 
(i)  Investing in civil works and medical equipment, which should be accompanied by 
adequate marketing of the upgraded services to the population that could profit 
from these services. Such investments would further need to be supported by 
human resources management and incentives for health staff to work, or to 
continue working, in the newly built or equipped health care facilities. 
(ii)  Reforming the health care financing system by making a choice for a budget-
funded system or a health insurance-funded system, thereby creating a single-
payer system, together with giving autonomy to public hospitals that can enter 
into contracts with either PHIC or regional health authorities.  
(iii)  Creating a regulatory environment conducive to transparency in both financing 
and  health  care  performance  while  providing  performance  monitoring  for 
providers to ensure access to care, quality of care, and value for money.  
(iv)  Introducing an effective referral system via PHIC staff acting as gatekeepers, 
accompanied by higher copayments when seeking higher levels of care without 
referral (except in accidents and specific emergencies) to ensure that patients 
make effective use of existing and upgraded facilities,

38.  Creating Investment Opportunities. Unfortunately, DOH’s funds for investment are

1.  The  credit  policy  framework  of  local  government  units  (LGUs)  guides  government 
financial institutions (GFIs) and the Municipal Development Fund Office (MDFO) on how to 
provide their financial and technical assistance to LGUs. It comprises four clusters based on 
LGU creditworthiness and the types of projects to be undertaken.  
(i)  Creditworthy LGUs with revenue-generating projects can be funded mostly from 
private sources of capital or GFIs (own funds).  
(ii)  Marginally or non-creditworthy LGUs with revenue-generating projects can be 
funded from GFI loans and limited MDFO loans.  
(iii)  Creditworthy LGUs undertaking social and environmental projects whose returns 
are low or long in coming could be allowed to tap longer-term, lower-cost official 
development assistance funds through loans from GFIs or MDFO.  
(iv)  Marginally  or  non-creditworthy  LGUs  with  social  and  environmental  projects 
could  be  assisted  by  loans  and  grants  from  MDFO  in  accordance  with  the 
approved policy of the National Economic and Development Authority Investment 
Coordination Committee.  
In short, for health projects, LGUs have a choice of seeking credit from GFIs or MDFO, and 
those LGUs that are creditworthy are expected to gravitate toward GFIs.  
 
2.  Where credit is not easily accessible for long-term investments from the private financial 
markets, the Government offers LGUs alternate public sourced of credit through MDFO,1 the 
GFIs,2 and  the  multilateral-  or  bilateral-financed  projects  of  the  central  Government.  The 
Government has a comprehensive credit policy framework for LGUs under which the lower

from MDFO, which provides a combination of loans and grants, as MDFO policies are pro-poor 
and it is willing to offer credit even without LGUs showing their creditworthiness; and the 
medium-to-higher fiscal capacity LGUs (levels 1–2) and city-based projects, along with those

1.  Eligibility  Criteria  for  Subborrowers.  Eligible subborrowers will be from among the

midwife or birthing clinics, pharmacies and small drugstores;  
(ii)  secondary and tertiary level public hospitals, especially for attention to maternal 
and child care, for the prevention of noncommunicable diseases, and in support of 
PHC (including telemedicine); 
(iii)  laboratories and diagnostic centers, preferably integrated into larger health care 
facilities such as hospitals; 
(iv)  business  solution  companies  or  nongovernment  organizations  supporting  or 
operating PHC clinics, hospitals, and their networks, as well as offering other ways 
of support for providers that reduce operating costs and increase effectiveness; 
(v)  drugs procurement and distribution companies willing also to distribute generics 
and to cover rural and remote areas; 
(vi)  networks offering some or all of the above; and 
(vii)  microfinance institutions, local banks, and small onlending cooperatives complying 
with the general and specific conditions of the program. 
 
2.  Eligibility Criteria for Subprojects. The above entities would be eligible if they show 
well-documented evidence that the subprojects meet the following:

Health's  (DOH's)  certificate  of  needs  for  new  health  facilities  and  permit  to 
construct (public sector);  
(ii)  for hospitals, a hospital diagnostic center or hospital development plan, including 
feasibility, financial sustainability, and utilization forecasts; 
(iii)  location in an underserved area; 
(iv)  are licensed or accredited by DOH and/or Bureau of Food and Drugs and/or 
Philippine International Trading Corporation and/or the Philippine Health Insurance 
Corporation; 
(v)  for local government units (LGUs), have the commitment of the LGU for funding 
operations and maintenance cost; and 
(vi)  comply with the Government’s and the Asian Development Bank’s environmental 
and social safeguard policies.  
 
3.  The Development Bank of the Philippines also uses its standard financial performance 
criteria to select subprojects:  
(i)  financial performance as shown by the applicant’s 3-year balance sheets and 
income-expenditure statements; 
(ii)  track record in borrowing and repayment; 
(iii)  projected cash flows for the period of borrowing; 
(iv)  such performance indicators as capital adequacy ratio, liquidity ratio, and debt 
repayment capacity; 
(v)  subproject management capacity, as to the availability staffing; 
(vi)   for financial intermediaries, additional performance indicators include (a) leverage 
ratio, and (b) membership portfolio and operational sustainability; and 
(vii)  for LGUs, additional performance indicators include borrowing capacity, as certified 
by the Bureau of Local Government Finance.

A.  Background 
 
1.  The  Development  Bank  of  the  Philippines  (DBP)  was  created  in  1986  pursuant  to 
Executive Order No. 81 dated 3 December 1986, as amended by Republic Act No. 8523 , as a 
government financing institution aimed at providing credit facilities for the development and 
expansion of Philippine agriculture and industry. It had an initial capitalization of P5.0 billion. 
 
2.  In 1995, the Monetary Board of the Central Bank of the Philippines (Bangko Sentral ng 
Pilipinas  [BSP])  granted  DBP  an  expanded  banking  license,  to  that  of  a  universal  bank,1 
authorizing a broad range of wholesale and retail credit facilities. DBP serves as a conduit for 
international funds from multilateral sources and bilateral institutions for official development 
assistance programs and grants. 
 
3.  Republic Act No. 8523 of February 1998 aimed to promote the bank’s growth, stability, 
and long-term viability by (i) increasing DBP’s authorized capital stock from P5 billion to P35 
billion, (ii) creating the position of president and chief executive officer who will also serve as 
vice chairperson of the DBP board of directors, and (iii) exempting DBP from coverage by the 
Salary Standardization Law, 2008. 
 
B.   Corporate Powers of DBP 
 
4.  The DBP is subject to the regulations of the BSP. The bank’s corporate powers include 
the following:2 
(i)  to grant loans to local governments and private sector entities for purposes of 
rehabilitation, establishment, or development of any agricultural and/or industrial 
enterprise,  including  public  utilities,  infrastructure  projects,  mining,  livestock 
industry, and fishing, whether offshore or inland; 
(ii)  to grant loans to cooperative associations, individual employees of public and 
private  corporations  to  facilitate  agricultural  and  other  industrial  production,  
marketing,  and the acquisition of essential commodities; 
(iii)  to underwrite, purchase, own, sell, mortgage, or otherwise dispose of stocks, 
bonds, debentures, securities, and other evidences of indebtedness issued for or 
in connection with any project or enterprise for self-liquidating purposes and carry 
on the business of a trust corporation; and 
(iv)  to organize, establish, and operate subsidiary corporations whenever necessary 
to better achieve DBP’s objectives.

members from the private sector, all subject to appointment by the President of the Philippines.

bank’s day-to-day operations, a senior executive vice president is appointed as chief operating 
officer. The bank’s major departments include the following: Trust Services, Program Lending

The Kapit Bisig Laban sa Kahirapan (KALAHI), which means linking arms against poverty, was launched in 2001 as the

for microfinance for livelihood development and basic infrastructure investment, including in barangay health stations.

MDGs by improving access to basic health services (component i) while creating employment and livelihood opportunities 
(component iii) with the participation of government, the private sector, and NGOs. The Project provides an innovative package 
of health industry financial services enabling health service sector professionals to establish or expand their services. A 
significant portion of the investment will be for such micro-health enterprises as birthing homes and distributors and retailers of

financial intermediary) to borrow for their health investment needs. The Project encourages public–private partnerships by 
enabling the public sector to guarantee a minimum level of income to private investors, thus resulting in increased provision of

partners in the Project by facilitating accreditation and expansion plus timely reimbursements of health care delivery costs.

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
The Project’s ultimate beneficiaries are women, children, indigents and the ill, and families.  
 
Women bear multiple costs of inadequate access to health care in their reproductive and child-rearing roles. Maternal mortality 
is intractably high. Fifty-five percent of all Filipino women deliver at home. Yet one of the major interventions to reduce maternal 
mortality and improve neonatal survival is for a woman to deliver at a properly equipped health facility attended by a 
professional. Location plays a large role in determining place of delivery. In rural areas, 43% of women in the highest income 
quintile deliver at home, while among their better-served urban counterparts only 17% of women in the highest income quintile 
deliver at home.c The most frequently cited reason for women delivering at home is cost. Hospital delivery is expensive. Public 
programs provide free antenatal care for poor women but not the cost of delivery. Facilitating PHIC accreditation of service 
providers, including midwives, reduces patient out-of-pocket costs and brings quality obstetric care closer to home at a 
significantly lower cost. 
 
The leading causes of death among children under 5 years old are largely preventable: pneumonia, diarrhea, and measles. 
Poor access to PHC results in underutilization, thus transforming manageable illnesses into catastrophic events. The rural 
health units (RHUs) are often understaffed and essential drugs stocked-out, thus constraining their support to the barangay 
health station (BHS) front-line care and public outreach programs. RHUs and BHSs jointly provide 50% of all outpatient care. 
Upgrading rural health units performance is key to effectively delivering PHC and reducing the leading causes of under-5 
mortality. 
 
The same proportion of poor and nonpoor—many of whom are near-poor—self-medicate when ill. The most significant 
difference between poor and nonpoor is in the choice of service provider; the public sector provides more than half of all care for 
the poor and nonpoor.d The private sector also serves a surprisingly large proportion of the poor. In Metro Manila, the poor 
almost exclusively use the public health system for outpatient care, and 60% make use of city and barangay health services. 
The public sector serves about 60% of the nonpoor. Outside of Metro Manila, 75% of the poor utilize the public health system for 
outpatient services compared to about 60% of the non-poor. The private sector provides the balance. While private sector 
medical care is sometimes viewed as beyond the reach of the poor, it is in fact an important partner to government in providing 
health care services to the poor.
